section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: In this hands-on programming section, students will learn the fundamentals of Python variables and data types through practical exercises and real-world examples. The section covers variable declaration, naming conventions, data type operations, and type conversion techniques essential for building Python applications.
learning_objectives: Declare variables using proper Python syntax and naming conventions
Identify and use different Python data types including integers, floats, strings, and booleans
Perform operations and manipulations on various data types
Convert between different data types using built-in Python functions
Debug and resolve common variable and data type errors

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to declare variables using appropriate naming conventions and assign values correctly.
key_topics: Variable assignment using the equals operator
Python naming rules and PEP 8 conventions
Multiple variable assignment in a single line

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create 5 variables with meaningful names to store personal information: name (string), age (integer), height_in_feet (float), is_student (boolean), and gpa (float). Follow Python naming conventions and print each variable with a descriptive label.

Identify and fix the naming errors in the following code: 1st_name = 'John', last-name = 'Doe', class = 'Python 101', studentGPA = 3.8. Rename each variable following proper conventions and demonstrate the corrected code works.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform arithmetic operations and distinguish between integer and float data types.
key_topics: Mathematical functions in the math module

exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a program that calculates the area of a circle using the formula πr². Use a radius of 5.5, store it as a variable, and display the result. Then modify the program to calculate the circumference using 2πr.

Create variables to store temperature in Celsius (25°C). Convert it to Fahrenheit using the formula F = (C × 9/5) + 32. Display both temperatures with appropriate labels. Test with multiple Celsius values.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create, concatenate, and manipulate string data using Python string methods.
key_topics: String creation with single, double, and triple quotes
Common string methods (upper, lower, strip, split, join)

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for first_name, last_name, and age. Format them into a sentence using three different methods: concatenation, f-strings, and the format() method. Display all three versions.

Given the string '  Python is FUN and Powerful!  ', write code to: (1) Remove leading/trailing spaces, (2) convert to lowercase, (3) split into words, (4) count the number of characters, and (5) replace 'fun' with 'exciting'. Print each result.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert between data types and check variable types using appropriate functions.
key_topics: Using int(), float(), str(), bool() functions
Type checking with type() and isinstance()

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create the following variables: num_str = '123', float_num = 45.67, bool_val = True. Convert each to the other three data types and print the results. Note any unexpected conversions and explain them.

Write a program that prompts for user's age as input, converts it to an integer, and calculates the birth year (assuming current year is 2024). Include error handling for non-numeric input and display appropriate messages for valid and invalid inputs.
